definition: to take up one's pen/to start to write
to carry (hanging down from the hand)/to lift/to put forward/to mention/to raise (an issue)/upwards character stroke/lifting brush stroke (in painting)/scoop for measuring liquid
pen/pencil/writing brush/to write or compose/the strokes of Chinese characters/classifier for sums of money, deals/CL:支[zhi1],枝[zhi1]
to have difficulty remembering how to write Chinese characters

sentences.english: Thinking over for a long time, finally I made up my mind to write the letter.
sentences.chinese: 想了好久，終於還是下定決心提筆寫了這封信。

sentences.english: Fan Zhongyan felt his friend's words were reasonable so he changed the word with pleasure.
sentences.chinese: 范仲淹覺得朋友說得有道理，欣然提筆改爲這個字。

sentences.english: Pick up a pen the moment, thoughts had returned to the Hometown of the autumn.
sentences.chinese: 提筆的瞬間，思緒就已回到了故園的秋。

sentences.english: With the advent of computers, putting pen to forget the phenomenon of word more and more.
sentences.chinese: 隨着電腦的出現，提筆忘字的現象越來越多。

sentences.english: He that can compose himself is wiser than he that composes books.
sentences.chinese: 能夠平撫自己的情緒，比能夠提筆寫書更有智慧。

definition: to put pen to paper/pen mark
to write or draw with a brush/to put pen to paper/to write
vigor of strokes in calligraphy or drawing/vigor of style in literary composition
nib/pen point/the tip of a writing brush or pencil
rough sketch (of a painting)/(of an official) to approve a document by signing it
